elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively investigated as Lewis acidic catalysts for a variety of reactions. However, the identity and nature of the MOF nodes in the catalysis remain ill-defined. Herein, a series of isostructural MOFs (M-NU-1008), with M being hexanuclear clusters of transition metals (Zr and Hf), a lanthanide (Ce), or an actinide (Th), were successfully synthesized and evaluated as Lewis acid catalysts, and CO2 cycloaddition of styrene oxide was used as a test reaction. Superior catalytic activity was observed with Ce-NU-1008 over the other M6-based MOFs. In addition to the different Lewis acidities among the metals in the four M-NU-1008, the dissociation of terminal water molecules from the M6 clusters before exposing the Lewis acidic metal sites was found to vary between the MOFs, as supported by variable-temperature diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy studies. In the MOFs where water dissociation from the metal nodes readily occurs, the catalytic activity is higher than the MOFs where water is bound more strongly. Upon further investigation, Hf-NU-1008-dehy with terminal water partially removed was found to exhibit enhanced activity compared to the as-prepared catalyst.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively investigated as Lewis acidic catalysts for a variety of reactions. However, the identity and nature of the MOF nodes in the catalysis remain ill-defined. Herein, a series of isostructural MOFs (M-NU-1008), with M being hexanuclear clusters of transition metals (Zr and Hf), a lanthanide (Ce), or an actinide (Th), were successfully synthesized and evaluated as Lewis acid catalysts, and CO2 cycloaddition of styrene oxide was used as a test reaction. Superior catalytic activity was observed with Ce-NU-1008 over the other M6-based MOFs. In addition to the different Lewis acidities among the metals in the four M-NU-1008, the dissociation of terminal water molecules from the M6 clusters before exposing the Lewis acidic metal sites was found to vary between the MOFs, as supported by variable-temperature diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy studies. In the MOFs where water dissociation from the metal nodes readily occurs, the catalytic activity is higher than the MOFs where water is bound more strongly. Upon further investigation, Hf-NU-1008-dehy with terminal water partially removed was found to exhibit enhanced activity compared to the as-prepared catalyst.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of porous, crystalline materials built from the coordination between metal ions or clusters and multitopic organic linkers. Their outstanding properties, such as high internal surface areas and inherent tunabilities, endow MOFs with strong potential in applications including but not limited to storage and separations, drug delivery, sensors, and catalysis. Since the first report of UiO-66, a MOF constructed from Zr6 clusters (Zr6(μ-O)4(μ-OH)4) and terephthalate linkers, Zr6-based MOFs have been extensively investigated due to their exceptional stability and structural robustness where impressive activities either as heterogeneous catalysts or as solid catalyst supports have been reported. On the one hand, substrate-accessible Lewis acidic Zr6 clusters in the structure make Zr6-based MOFs intriguing candidates as solid acid catalysts for the instantaneous destruction of chemical warfare agents or the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides. On the other hand, plentiful anchoring sites including terminal hydroxyl (Zr–OH), terminal water (Zr–OH2), and bridging hydroxyl (Zr–OH–Zr) moieties on the well-defined and isolated Zr6 clusters make these MOFs good supports in various chemical processes. Besides Zr, structural analogs using Hf and Ce clusters as MOF nodes have also been reported in Lewis acidic M6-based MOFs. However, systematic investigations into the exact role that M6 clusters play (either as acid catalysts or catalyst supports) are still rare.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of porous, crystalline materials built from the coordination between metal ions or clusters and multitopic organic linkers. Their outstanding properties, such as high internal surface areas and inherent tunabilities, endow MOFs with strong potential in applications including but not limited to storage and separations, drug delivery, sensors, and catalysis. Since the first report of UiO-66, a MOF constructed from Zr6 clusters (Zr6(μ-O)4(μ-OH)4) and terephthalate linkers, Zr6-based MOFs have been extensively investigated due to their exceptional stability and structural robustness where impressive activities either as heterogeneous catalysts or as solid catalyst supports have been reported. On the one hand, substrate-accessible Lewis acidic Zr6 clusters in the structure make Zr6-based MOFs intriguing candidates as solid acid catalysts for the instantaneous destruction of chemical warfare agents or the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides. On the other hand, plentiful anchoring sites including terminal hydroxyl (Zr-OH), terminal water (Zr-OH2), and bridging hydroxyl (Zr-OH-Zr) moieties on the well-defined and isolated Zr6 clusters make these MOFs good supports in various chemical processes. Besides Zr, structural analogs using Hf and Ce clusters as MOF nodes have also been reported in Lewis acidic M6-based MOFs. However, systematic investigations into the exact role that M6 clusters play (either as acid catalysts or catalyst supports) are still rare.

elements.content: In order to discern how the identity of the M6 clusters affects catalysis, one can compare activities of isostructural MOFs with different metal species. In the group IV elements, transition metals Zr­(IV) and Hf­(IV) were mostly investigated as the metal sources instead of lanthanide Ce­(IV) and actinide Th­(IV). Our group has previously reported that catalytic CO2 fixation can be achieved under mild conditions with mesoporous Zr-NU-1000 and Hf-NU-1000 as Lewis acid catalysts, a more favorable route than the energy-demanding conditions needed when using other MOFs. In addition, impressive potential of microporous Ce-UiO-66 as a Lewis acid catalyst has been indicated with superior activity in the hydrolysis of a nerve agent than Zr-UiO-66, which strongly motivated the interest in mesoporous Ce6-based MOFs for improved catalytic performance on various processes. However, mesoporous Ce6-based MOF synthesis with uniform crystalline texture and high surface area remains a challenge due to the ease of reducing the metal ions from Ce4+ to Ce3+. Moreover, a few examples have used Th­(IV), an actinide metal ion, as a metal source for microporous MOF synthesis, and even fewer examples of mesoporous Th6-based MOFs have been reported. Even though some efforts have been devoted to determining the critical role of M6 clusters as Lewis acid catalysts through comparing two isostructural M6-based (M = Zr or Hf) MOFs, systematic studies to deconvolute these roles remain a challenge, which is largely due to the underexplored chemistry on the preparation of Ce6- or Th6-based MOFs. Inspired by these previous studies, this report aims to elucidate the roles of these metal clusters, as Lewis acid catalysts, by the systematic study of a series of isostructural M6-based MOFs from transition metals (Zr and Hf) to lanthanide (Ce) and actinide (Th) for the model reaction of CO2 cyclization into styrene oxide.
elements.clean_text: In order to discern how the identity of the M6 clusters affects catalysis, one can compare activities of isostructural MOFs with different metal species. In the group IV elements, transition metals Zr(IV) and Hf(IV) were mostly investigated as the metal sources instead of lanthanide Ce(IV) and actinide Th(IV). Our group has previously reported that catalytic CO2 fixation can be achieved under mild conditions with mesoporous Zr-NU-1000 and Hf-NU-1000 as Lewis acid catalysts, a more favorable route than the energy-demanding conditions needed when using other MOFs. In addition, impressive potential of microporous Ce-UiO-66 as a Lewis acid catalyst has been indicated with superior activity in the hydrolysis of a nerve agent than Zr-UiO-66, which strongly motivated the interest in mesoporous Ce6-based MOFs for improved catalytic performance on various processes. However, mesoporous Ce6-based MOF synthesis with uniform crystalline texture and high surface area remains a challenge due to the ease of reducing the metal ions from Ce4+ to Ce3+. Moreover, a few examples have used Th(IV), an actinide metal ion, as a metal source for microporous MOF synthesis, and even fewer examples of mesoporous Th6-based MOFs have been reported. Even though some efforts have been devoted to determining the critical role of M6 clusters as Lewis acid catalysts through comparing two isostructural M6-based (M = Zr or Hf) MOFs, systematic studies to deconvolute these roles remain a challenge, which is largely due to the underexplored chemistry on the preparation of Ce6- or Th6-based MOFs. Inspired by these previous studies, this report aims to elucidate the roles of these metal clusters, as Lewis acid catalysts, by the systematic study of a series of isostructural M6-based MOFs from transition metals (Zr and Hf) to lanthanide (Ce) and actinide (Th) for the model reaction of CO2 cyclization into styrene oxide.

elements.content: With the design of hierarchical channels and the nature of mesoporosity, a series of csq -net isostructural MOFs were designed and synthesized (NU-1008, ), which were constructed from 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene (TCPB-Br2) linkers and different M6 clusters, ranging from transition metals (Zr and Hf), lanthanide metal (Ce), and actinide metal (Th).
elements.clean_text: With the design of hierarchical channels and the nature of mesoporosity, a series of  csq -net isostructural MOFs were designed and synthesized (NU-1008, ), which were constructed from 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (TCPB-Br2) linkers and different M6 clusters, ranging from transition metals (Zr and Hf), lanthanide metal (Ce), and actinide metal (Th).

elements.content: Schematic representation of the construction of four M6 clusters and M-NU-1008. Lime green = Zr, blue = Hf, yellow = Ce, green-blue = Th, gray = C, red = O, purple = Br.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic representation of the construction of four M6 clusters and M-NU-1008. Lime green = Zr, blue = Hf, yellow = Ce, green-blue = Th, gray = C, red = O, purple = Br.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Zirconium­(IV) oxynitrate hydrate (99%), hafnium­(IV) chloride (99%), ammonium cerium­(IV) nitrate (99%), thorium nitrate hydrate (≥98%), formic acid (≥96%), benzoic acid (99%), and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) (99.9%), acetone (99.8%), styrene oxide (99%), tetrabutylammonium bromide, and acetonitrile (99%) were purchased from Fisher Chemical. Deionized water was used as the water source throughout the experiments. Bone dry grade CO2 was used as the CO2 source for cycloaddition reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals and Materials

All chemicals and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Zirconium(IV) oxynitrate hydrate (99%), hafnium(IV) chloride (99%), ammonium cerium(IV) nitrate (99%), thorium nitrate hydrate (≥98%), formic acid (≥96%), benzoic acid (99%), and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) (99.9%), acetone (99.8%), styrene oxide (99%), tetrabutylammonium bromide, and acetonitrile (99%) were purchased from Fisher Chemical. Deionized water was used as the water source throughout the experiments. Bone dry grade CO2 was used as the CO2 source for cycloaddition reaction.

elements.content:
Caution! Thorium nitrate (Th­(NO3)4·5H2O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant, so precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances have been followed.

Synthesis of <bold>Zr-NU-1008</bold>

Zirconium oxynitrate hydrate (0.267 mmol, 66.4 mg) and 1 mL of formic acid were added to DMF (1.5 mL) to obtain the Zr6 cluster solution by heating the mixture at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling down the mixture, a solution prepared by dissolving TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg) in 1.5 mL of DMF was added into the prepared node solution. The mixture was heated under 100 °C overnight (15–16 h). The generated white powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Caution!  Thorium nitrate (Th(NO3)4⋅5H2O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant, so precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances have been followed.

Synthesis of Zr-NU-1008 

Zirconium oxynitrate hydrate (0.267 mmol, 66.4 mg) and 1 mL of formic acid were added to DMF (1.5 mL) to obtain the Zr6 cluster solution by heating the mixture at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling down the mixture, a solution prepared by dissolving TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg) in 1.5 mL of DMF was added into the prepared node solution. The mixture was heated under 100 °C overnight (15-16 h). The generated white powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

elements.content: Hafnium chloride (0.267 mmol, 85.4 mg), TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg), and 1 mL of formic acid were added to DMF (1.5 mL). The mixture was sonicated and then heated under 100 °C overnight (15–16 h). The generated white powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Hf-NU-1008 Powder

Hafnium chloride (0.267 mmol, 85.4 mg), TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg), and 1 mL of formic acid were added to DMF (1.5 mL). The mixture was sonicated and then heated under 100 °C overnight (15-16 h). The generated white powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

elements.content: Hafnium dichloride oxide octahydrate (0.008 mmol, 1.87 mg) and 30 μL of formic acid were added to DEF (0.5 mL) to obtain the Hf6 cluster solution by heating the mixture at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling down the mixture, a solution prepared by dissolving TCPB-Br2 (0.0013 mmol, 0.965 mg) in 0.5 mL of DEF was added into the prepared node solution. Additional 0.45 mL of formic acid was added. After heating at 120 °C for 3 days, rod-shaped single crystals formed.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Hf-NU-1008 Single Crystal

Hafnium dichloride oxide octahydrate (0.008 mmol, 1.87 mg) and 30 μL of formic acid were added to DEF (0.5 mL) to obtain the Hf6 cluster solution by heating the mixture at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling down the mixture, a solution prepared by dissolving TCPB-Br2 (0.0013 mmol, 0.965 mg) in 0.5 mL of DEF was added into the prepared node solution. Additional 0.45 mL of formic acid was added. After heating at 120 °C for 3 days, rod-shaped single crystals formed.

elements.content: In a 1.5 dram vial with TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg) dissolved in 1.2 mL of DMF, aqueous ammonium cerium nitrate solution (0.4 mL, 1.066 M) and formic acid (0.258 mL) were added in sequence. The mixture was placed on the aluminum hot plate and then stirred under 100 °C for 5 min. The generated light-yellow powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ce-NU-1008 

In a 1.5 dram vial with TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg) dissolved in 1.2 mL of DMF, aqueous ammonium cerium nitrate solution (0.4 mL, 1.066 M) and formic acid (0.258 mL) were added in sequence. The mixture was placed on the aluminum hot plate and then stirred under 100 °C for 5 min. The generated light-yellow powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

elements.content: 400 μL of solution A (1000 mg Th­(NO3)4·5H2O dissolved in 20 mL DMF) and 400 μL of solution B (100 mg TCPB-Br2 in 10 mL DMF) were added to a 1.5 dram vial with 100 μL of H2O, and 100 μL of solution C (5 g benzoic acid in 10 mL DMF) was added, resulting in a clear solution. Twenty sample vials were prepared under the same conditions at once and were placed into an oil bath at 120 °C for 30 min, during which time a white suspension formed. After cooling down to room temperature, the 20 vials were combined, and the solid was isolated by centrifugation. The sample was further washed with DMF and then soaked in formic acid/DMF (1:10) overnight to replace benzoic acid with formic acid. After benzoic acid removal, the material was further washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Th-NU-1008 

400 μL of solution A (1000 mg Th(NO3)4⋅5H2O dissolved in 20 mL DMF) and 400 μL of solution B (100 mg TCPB-Br2 in 10 mL DMF) were added to a 1.5 dram vial with 100 μL of H2O, and 100 μL of solution C (5 g benzoic acid in 10 mL DMF) was added, resulting in a clear solution. Twenty sample vials were prepared under the same conditions at once and were placed into an oil bath at 120 °C for 30 min, during which time a white suspension formed. After cooling down to room temperature, the 20 vials were combined, and the solid was isolated by centrifugation. The sample was further washed with DMF and then soaked in formic acid/DMF (1:10) overnight to replace benzoic acid with formic acid. After benzoic acid removal, the material was further washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer model SmartLab equipped with an 18 kW Cu rotating anode, an MLO monochromator, and a high-count-rate scintillation detector. Measurements were made over the range of 1° < 2θ < 30° in a 0.05° step width with a 5°/min scanning speed.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction Analyses

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer model SmartLab equipped with an 18 kW Cu rotating anode, an MLO monochromator, and a high-count-rate scintillation detector. Measurements were made over the range of 1° < 2θ < 30° in a 0.05° step width with a 5°/min scanning speed.

elements.content: N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms on activated materials were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA) instrument at 77 K. Around 30 mg of the sample was used in each measurement, and the specific surface areas were determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller model from the N2 sorption data in the region P/P 0 = 0.005–0.05. Pore size distributions were obtained by DFT calculations using a carbon slit-pore model with a N2 kernel.
elements.clean_text:
N2 Sorption Measurements

N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms on activated materials were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA) instrument at 77 K. Around 30 mg of the sample was used in each measurement, and the specific surface areas were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller model from the N2 sorption data in the region P/P 0 = 0.005-0.05. Pore size distributions were obtained by DFT calculations using a carbon slit-pore model with a N2 kernel.

elements.content: MOF samples (∼1 mg) were digested with NaOD solution (0.1 M in deuterium oxide, 150 μL). After sonication for 20 min, another 500 μL of deuterium oxide was added into the mixture to dilute the solution. Proton NMR spectra were collected on a Bruker Avance III 500 MHz system equipped with a DCH CryoProbe and automated with a BACS-60 autosampler.
elements.clean_text:
Proton NMR

MOF samples (~1 mg) were digested with NaOD solution (0.1 M in deuterium oxide, 150 μL). After sonication for 20 min, another 500 μL of deuterium oxide was added into the mixture to dilute the solution. Proton NMR spectra were collected on a Bruker Avance III 500 MHz system equipped with a DCH CryoProbe and automated with a BACS-60 autosampler.

elements.content: DRIFTS spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector. The detector was cooled with liquid N2, and the spectra were collected under an Ar atmosphere. KBr was utilized as a background spectrum.
elements.clean_text:
Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS)

DRIFTS spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector. The detector was cooled with liquid N2, and the spectra were collected under an Ar atmosphere. KBr was utilized as a background spectrum.

elements.content: Batch reactions were carried out in a Parr reactor by using M-NU-1008 as catalysts for CO2 fixation into styrene oxide. Styrene oxide (0.2 mmol), tetrabutylammonium bromide (6.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) predissolved in 400 μL of acetonitrile, and MOF material (0.002 mmol) were added to an autoclave reactor, which was previously dried for 6 h at 80 °C. The autoclave reactor was evacuated, purged with CO2, and then placed under a constant pressure of CO2 at 5 bar for 15 min to allow the system to equilibrate. Then the pressure was reduced to 1 bar of gauge pressure, and the reaction was carried out at room temperature. After catalyst separation by centrifugation, a small aliquot of the supernatant reaction mixture was taken to be analyzed by 1H NMR to calculate the conversion of the reaction.
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Cycloaddition of Styrene Oxide

Batch reactions were carried out in a Parr reactor by using M-NU-1008 as catalysts for CO2 fixation into styrene oxide. Styrene oxide (0.2 mmol), tetrabutylammonium bromide (6.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) predissolved in 400 μL of acetonitrile, and MOF material (0.002 mmol) were added to an autoclave reactor, which was previously dried for 6 h at 80 °C. The autoclave reactor was evacuated, purged with CO2, and then placed under a constant pressure of CO2 at 5 bar for 15 min to allow the system to equilibrate. Then the pressure was reduced to 1 bar of gauge pressure, and the reaction was carried out at room temperature. After catalyst separation by centrifugation, a small aliquot of the supernatant reaction mixture was taken to be analyzed by 1H NMR to calculate the conversion of the reaction.

elements.content: The four M6-based MOFs (M-NU-1008) were solvothermally synthesized as bulk powders and/or as single crystals in N,N-dimethylformamide or N,N-diethylformamide with formic acid as the modulator except for Th-NU-1008, which was modulated by benzoic acid. By varying the amount of modulators, hexagonal rod-shaped single crystals of Zr-NU-1008, Hf-NU-1008 (Hf6(μ-O)4­(μ-OH)4­(HCOO)0.5­(H2O)3.5­(OH)3.5­(TCPB-Br2)2), and Th-NU-1008 were obtained. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (Table S1) revealed that all the three materials crystallized in the same hexagonal P6/mmm space group with slightly increasing unit cell dimensions; the 3D structure consists of 8-connected M6 nodes and TCPB-Br2 linkers in a csq topology. M-NU-1008 possess two types of channels along the c axis, a 1 nm wide triangular channel, and a 3 nm hexagonal channel (); this hierarchical design ensures the accessibility of substrates to the Lewis acidic sites. Interestingly, unlike Zr-NU-1008 and Hf-NU-1008 with identical eight-coordinated metal ions, the single-crystal diffraction analysis of Th-NU-1008 revealed that each Th site in the Th6 clusters was nine-coordinated with an extra terminal water (Th–OH2), similar to what was observed previously in Th-UiO-66. Attempts to grow single crystals of Ce-NU-1008 were hindered by the instant nucleation of microcrystals and instability in solvents at high temperatures; the isostructural nature of the Ce MOF was confirmed through analysis of the bulk material instead.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of M-NU-1008 

The four M6-based MOFs (M-NU-1008) were solvothermally synthesized as bulk powders and/or as single crystals in N,N-dimethylformamide or N,N-diethylformamide with formic acid as the modulator except for Th-NU-1008, which was modulated by benzoic acid. By varying the amount of modulators, hexagonal rod-shaped single crystals of Zr-NU-1008, Hf-NU-1008 (Hf6(μ-O)4(μ-OH)4(HCOO)0.5(H2O)3.5(OH)3.5(TCPB-Br2)2), and Th-NU-1008  were obtained. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (Table S1) revealed that all the three materials crystallized in the same hexagonal P6/mmm space group with slightly increasing unit cell dimensions; the 3D structure consists of 8-connected M6 nodes and TCPB-Br2 linkers in a  csq  topology. M-NU-1008 possess two types of channels along the c axis, a 1 nm wide triangular channel, and a 3 nm hexagonal channel (); this hierarchical design ensures the accessibility of substrates to the Lewis acidic sites. Interestingly, unlike Zr-NU-1008 and Hf-NU-1008 with identical eight-coordinated metal ions, the single-crystal diffraction analysis of Th-NU-1008  revealed that each Th site in the Th6 clusters was nine-coordinated with an extra terminal water (Th-OH2), similar to what was observed previously in Th-UiO-66. Attempts to grow single crystals of Ce-NU-1008 were hindered by the instant nucleation of microcrystals and instability in solvents at high temperatures; the isostructural nature of the Ce MOF was confirmed through analysis of the bulk material instead.

elements.content: The crystallinity of the four bulk MOFs were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (a). Scanning electron microscopy images revealed similar hexagonal rod-shaped morphology. Uniform particle sizes of four M-NU-1008 were obtained (∼1 μm, b) in order to eliminate possible interferences from intraparticle diffusion on catalytic performance. For consistency, benzoic acid capped on as-synthesized Th-NU-1008 was fully replaced post-synthetically with formic acid, allowable due to formic acid’s lower pK a than benzoic acid’s. Upon digestion of the MOF materials with dilute NaOD solution, NMR spectroscopic studies show a singlet at ∼ 8.37 ppm, which was attributed to the formate group, confirming the displacement of benzoic acid in Th-NU-1008. Integration of this peak relative to the organic linker in the four digested MOF samples gives the amounts of formate groups, which are approximately 3, 3, 2, and 3 in Zr-NU-1008, Hf-NU-1008, Ce-NU-1008, and Th-NU-1008, respectively (Figures S2–S5). Type IV nitrogen sorption isotherms were observed on all four materials, which indicate the presence of both micropores and mesopores (c). Given the different atomic weights of four metals, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) areas and pore volumes were calculated and normalized to be 930, 1030, 910, and 810 m2/cm3 and 0.63, 0.68, 0.52, and 0.51 cm3/cm3 for Zr-NU-1008, Hf-NU-1008, Ce-NU-1008, and Th-NU-1008, respectively. Hierarchical ∼1.1 nm micropores and ∼2.9 nm mesopores were observed in the DFT-calculated pore size distributions for all four materials, which provide sufficient pore space for the catalytic reaction in this study (d).
elements.clean_text: The crystallinity of the four bulk MOFs were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (a). Scanning electron microscopy images revealed similar hexagonal rod-shaped morphology. Uniform particle sizes of four M-NU-1008 were obtained (~1 μm, b) in order to eliminate possible interferences from intraparticle diffusion on catalytic performance. For consistency, benzoic acid capped on as-synthesized Th-NU-1008 was fully replaced post-synthetically with formic acid, allowable due to formic acid's lower pK a than benzoic acid's. Upon digestion of the MOF materials with dilute NaOD solution, NMR spectroscopic studies show a singlet at ~ 8.37 ppm, which was attributed to the formate group, confirming the displacement of benzoic acid in Th-NU-1008. Integration of this peak relative to the organic linker in the four digested MOF samples gives the amounts of formate groups, which are approximately 3, 3, 2, and 3 in Zr-NU-1008, Hf-NU-1008, Ce-NU-1008, and Th-NU-1008, respectively (Figures S2-S5). Type IV nitrogen sorption isotherms were observed on all four materials, which indicate the presence of both micropores and mesopores (c). Given the different atomic weights of four metals, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) areas and pore volumes were calculated and normalized to be 930, 1030, 910, and 810 m2/cm3 and 0.63, 0.68, 0.52, and 0.51 cm3/cm3 for Zr-NU-1008, Hf-NU-1008, Ce-NU-1008, and Th-NU-1008, respectively. Hierarchical ~1.1 nm micropores and ~2.9 nm mesopores were observed in the DFT-calculated pore size distributions for all four materials, which provide sufficient pore space for the catalytic reaction in this study (d).

elements.content: (a) Powder X-ray diffraction patterns, (b) scanning electron microscopy images, (c) nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K, and (d) DFT-calculated pore size distributions of M-NU-1008.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Powder X-ray diffraction patterns, (b) scanning electron microscopy images, (c) nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K, and (d) DFT-calculated pore size distributions of M-NU-1008.

elements.content: CO2 fixation with styrene oxide was carried out with four activated M-NU-1008 as catalysts at room temperature under 1 bar­(g) of CO2 in the presence of the nBu4NBr cocatalyst (a). After 20 h, diverse catalytic performances were observed, while a blank control experiment with no catalyst showed negligible product formation under identical conditions (Table S2). The conversions of four MOFs were determined to be about 89, 16, 95, and 10 for Zr-, Hf-, Ce-, and Th-NU-1008, respectively. Interestingly, Zr-NU-1008 and Ce-NU-1008 exhibited much higher activity of CO2 fixation into styrene oxide than Hf-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1008 (b, Figure S10). Remarkably high catalytic activity was realized on Ce-NU-1008 with almost full conversion in 20 h, while poor activity was observed on Th-NU-1008 where only 65% conversion was observed after 72 h catalysis. For a better understanding, the catalytic process for each catalyst was monitored at 1 atm CO2 over time using NMR spectroscopy (Figures S11–S14). The slopes of the curves (time versus conversion) reflected the initial reaction rates of the four M-NU-1008 catalysts (Figure S15). Ce-NU-1008 exhibited 3-fold higher initial turnover frequency over the next best catalyst, Zr-NU-1008, further highlighting the superior catalytic activity of the Ce6-based MOF for CO2 cycloaddition over the other isostructural MOFs. In addition, good crystallinity was observed on all the four M-NU-1008 after catalysis, indicating their good stability during catalysis (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Cycloaddition of Styrene Oxide

CO2 fixation with styrene oxide was carried out with four activated M-NU-1008 as catalysts at room temperature under 1 bar(g) of CO2 in the presence of the nBu4NBr cocatalyst (a). After 20 h, diverse catalytic performances were observed, while a blank control experiment with no catalyst showed negligible product formation under identical conditions (Table S2). The conversions of four MOFs were determined to be about 89, 16, 95, and 10 for Zr-, Hf-, Ce-, and Th-NU-1008, respectively. Interestingly, Zr-NU-1008 and Ce-NU-1008 exhibited much higher activity of CO2 fixation into styrene oxide than Hf-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1008 (b, Figure S10). Remarkably high catalytic activity was realized on Ce-NU-1008 with almost full conversion in 20 h, while poor activity was observed on Th-NU-1008 where only 65% conversion was observed after 72 h catalysis. For a better understanding, the catalytic process for each catalyst was monitored at 1 atm CO2 over time using NMR spectroscopy (Figures S11-S14). The slopes of the curves (time versus conversion) reflected the initial reaction rates of the four M-NU-1008 catalysts (Figure S15). Ce-NU-1008 exhibited 3-fold higher initial turnover frequency over the next best catalyst, Zr-NU-1008, further highlighting the superior catalytic activity of the Ce6-based MOF for CO2 cycloaddition over the other isostructural MOFs. In addition, good crystallinity was observed on all the four M-NU-1008 after catalysis, indicating their good stability during catalysis (Figure S16).

elements.content: (a) Reaction scheme of CO2 fixation into styrene oxide; (b) CO2 fixation behavior on four M-NU-1008 and partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Reaction scheme of CO2 fixation into styrene oxide; (b) CO2 fixation behavior on four M-NU-1008 and partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008.

elements.content: Since the Lewis acidity of the metal sites plays an instrumental role in the catalytic activity of CO2 cycloaddition reactions, temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3) was conducted on four M-NU-1008 to characterize their acidity trend (Figure S7). The decreasing Lewis acidity of Zr > Hf > Ce was consistent with the increasing ionic radii of M­(IV). However, Th-NU-1008 with the largest ionic radii among four metals was observed with even higher Lewis acidity than Zr, which could result from the unique Th6 cluster structure fabricated with nine-coordinated Th­(IV) instead of eight-coordinated M­(IV) in other three materials. The lower temperature peak at around 250 °C in the TPD-NH3 profile of Ce-NU-1008 can be attributed to the existence of Ce3+ in the structure according to the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study (Figures S8 and S9). In the current series of isostructural comparisons, where the identity of the metal is the major difference between the catalysts, the observed trend of catalytic activity (Ce > Zr > Hf > Th) deviates from the strength of Lewis acidity (Th > Zr > Hf > Ce) by TPD-NH3. The inconsistency between the catalytic activity order and Lewis acidity order implies that factors other than Lewis acidity contribute to this reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Lewis Acidity of M-NU-1008 

Since the Lewis acidity of the metal sites plays an instrumental role in the catalytic activity of CO2 cycloaddition reactions, temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3) was conducted on four M-NU-1008 to characterize their acidity trend (Figure S7). The decreasing Lewis acidity of Zr > Hf > Ce was consistent with the increasing ionic radii of M(IV). However, Th-NU-1008 with the largest ionic radii among four metals was observed with even higher Lewis acidity than Zr, which could result from the unique Th6 cluster structure fabricated with nine-coordinated Th(IV) instead of eight-coordinated M(IV) in other three materials. The lower temperature peak at around 250 °C in the TPD-NH3 profile of Ce-NU-1008 can be attributed to the existence of Ce3+ in the structure according to the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study (Figures S8 and S9). In the current series of isostructural comparisons, where the identity of the metal is the major difference between the catalysts, the observed trend of catalytic activity (Ce > Zr > Hf > Th) deviates from the strength of Lewis acidity (Th > Zr > Hf > Ce) by TPD-NH3. The inconsistency between the catalytic activity order and Lewis acidity order implies that factors other than Lewis acidity contribute to this reaction.

elements.content: Based on a previous mechanistic report, we proposed that the dissociation of terminal water (M–OH2) from the metal before exposing the Lewis acidic sites affected catalysis (Figure S17). To test if this factored into our system, variable-temperature diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis was conducted on the four M-NU-1008 (). Two main peaks in the non-hydrogen-bonded O–H stretching region are attributed to terminal water M–OH2 (higher wavenumbers) and terminal hydroxyl groups M–OH (lower wavenumbers). Through heating the materials from room temperature up to 200 °C under argon flow, different rates and degrees of terminal water dissociation from four M6 clusters were observed at different temperatures, as indicated by the decreasing intensity of the terminal water peak. Specifically, the terminal water of Zr-NU-1008 started coming off at 180 °C, and complete dehydration was achieved after heating overnight at 200 °C, whereas only partial dehydration of the Hf-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1008 nodes was realized under the same conditions. The extra terminal water molecules on the Th6 cluster make this water dissociation process even harder. On the contrary, Ce Lewis acidic sites were more readily accessible as the complete dissociation of terminal water was observed at a lower temperature (120 °C).
elements.clean_text:
Role of Terminal Water Dissociation

Based on a previous mechanistic report, we proposed that the dissociation of terminal water (M-OH2) from the metal before exposing the Lewis acidic sites affected catalysis (Figure S17). To test if this factored into our system, variable-temperature diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis was conducted on the four M-NU-1008 (). Two main peaks in the non-hydrogen-bonded O-H stretching region are attributed to terminal water M-OH2 (higher wavenumbers) and terminal hydroxyl groups M-OH (lower wavenumbers). Through heating the materials from room temperature up to 200 °C under argon flow, different rates and degrees of terminal water dissociation from four M6 clusters were observed at different temperatures, as indicated by the decreasing intensity of the terminal water peak. Specifically, the terminal water of Zr-NU-1008 started coming off at 180 °C, and complete dehydration was achieved after heating overnight at 200 °C, whereas only partial dehydration of the Hf-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1008 nodes was realized under the same conditions. The extra terminal water molecules on the Th6 cluster make this water dissociation process even harder. On the contrary, Ce Lewis acidic sites were more readily accessible as the complete dissociation of terminal water was observed at a lower temperature (120 °C).

elements.content: Variable-temperature diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy spectra of four M-NU-1008.
elements.clean_text: 4  Variable-temperature diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy spectra of four M-NU-1008.

elements.content: To confirm the influence of water dissociation on catalysis, the partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 (Hf-NU-1008-dehy) was prepared for CO2 fixation by evacuating the sample at 150 °C for 20 h. The decrease of the Hf–OH2 peak at 3674 cm–1 in the DRIFTS spectrum of partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 confirmed the fractional removal of terminal water (a). In addition, no obvious changes of the BET area and pore volume were observed after dehydration (b,c). Compared to the as-prepared materials, the styrene oxide conversion on partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 was dramatically enhanced from 16% to 35% conversion under identical conditions (d), which is ascribed to the exposure of Lewis acidic metal sites after the partial dehydration of the metal nodes.
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Cycloaddition Catalyzed by Hf-NU-1008-dehy 

To confirm the influence of water dissociation on catalysis, the partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 (Hf-NU-1008-dehy) was prepared for CO2 fixation by evacuating the sample at 150 °C for 20 h. The decrease of the Hf-OH2 peak at 3674 cm-1 in the DRIFTS spectrum of partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 confirmed the fractional removal of terminal water (a). In addition, no obvious changes of the BET area and pore volume were observed after dehydration (b,c). Compared to the as-prepared materials, the styrene oxide conversion on partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 was dramatically enhanced from 16% to 35% conversion under identical conditions (d), which is ascribed to the exposure of Lewis acidic metal sites after the partial dehydration of the metal nodes.

elements.content: (a) Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy spectra, (b) nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K, (c) DFT-calculated pore size distributions of Hf-NU-1008 and Hf-NU-1008-dehy, and (d) 1H NMR (CDCl3, 500 MHz; red asterisk = product, red triangle = substrate, red diamond = nBu4NBr) of the reaction products catalyzed by Hf-NU-1008 and Hf-NU-1008-dehy.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy spectra, (b) nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K, (c) DFT-calculated pore size distributions of Hf-NU-1008 and Hf-NU-1008-dehy, and (d) 1H NMR (CDCl3, 500 MHz; red asterisk = product, red triangle = substrate, red diamond = nBu4NBr) of the reaction products catalyzed by Hf-NU-1008 and Hf-NU-1008-dehy.

elements.content: In conclusion, four isostructural mesoporous M-NU-1008 MOFs with transition metals (Zr and Hf), lanthanide (Ce), and actinide (Th) hexanuclear metal cluster nodes as Lewis acidic sites for CO2 fixation have been synthesized. Remarkable catalytic activity was observed on Ce-NU-1008 with full conversion of styrene oxide in 20 h under mild conditions, making Ce6-based MOFs promising Lewis acid catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reactions. By comparing the CO2 fixation conversions and variable-temperature DRIFTS spectra of the four M-NU-1008, the dissociation of terminal water from the metal nodes was found to correlate to activity. The proposed mechanism was further supported by the enhanced CO2 fixation performance on partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 compared to the as-prepared sample. By using structurally well-defined isostructural MOFs with different metal nodes, this work provides a systematic study of the Lewis acid catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition reaction and offers insight into how the node identity can affect catalysis, which will pave the way for designing Lewis acidic catalysts with improved activities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, four isostructural mesoporous M-NU-1008 MOFs with transition metals (Zr and Hf), lanthanide (Ce), and actinide (Th) hexanuclear metal cluster nodes as Lewis acidic sites for CO2 fixation have been synthesized. Remarkable catalytic activity was observed on Ce-NU-1008 with full conversion of styrene oxide in 20 h under mild conditions, making Ce6-based MOFs promising Lewis acid catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reactions. By comparing the CO2 fixation conversions and variable-temperature DRIFTS spectra of the four M-NU-1008, the dissociation of terminal water from the metal nodes was found to correlate to activity. The proposed mechanism was further supported by the enhanced CO2 fixation performance on partially dehydrated Hf-NU-1008 compared to the as-prepared sample. By using structurally well-defined isostructural MOFs with different metal nodes, this work provides a systematic study of the Lewis acid catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition reaction and offers insight into how the node identity can affect catalysis, which will pave the way for designing Lewis acidic catalysts with improved activities.

elements.content:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00960.

Crystallographic data for Hf-NU-1008 (CIF)

Materials synthesis, proton NMR spectra, TGA curves, temperature-programmed desorption profiles of MOF materials, XPS spectra of Ce-NU-1008, crystallographic data for Hf-NU-1008, CO2 fixation reaction using the catalysts, proposed reaction mechanism for CO2 cycloaddition to styrene oxide by M-NU-1008 and PXRD patterns of materials after catalysis (PDF)

cln_elements.content:
Caution! Thorium nitrate (Th­(NO3)4·5H2O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant, so precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances have been followed.

Synthesis of <bold>Zr-NU-1008</bold>

Zirconium oxynitrate hydrate (0.267 mmol, 66.4 mg) and 1 mL of formic acid were added to DMF (1.5 mL) to obtain the Zr6 cluster solution by heating the mixture at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling down the mixture, a solution prepared by dissolving TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg) in 1.5 mL of DMF was added into the prepared node solution. The mixture was heated under 100 °C overnight (15–16 h). The generated white powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

Synthesis of <bold>Hf-NU-1008</bold> Powder

Hafnium chloride (0.267 mmol, 85.4 mg), TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg), and 1 mL of formic acid were added to DMF (1.5 mL). The mixture was sonicated and then heated under 100 °C overnight (15–16 h). The generated white powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

Synthesis of <bold>Hf-NU-1008</bold> Single Crystal

Hafnium dichloride oxide octahydrate (0.008 mmol, 1.87 mg) and 30 μL of formic acid were added to DEF (0.5 mL) to obtain the Hf6 cluster solution by heating the mixture at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling down the mixture, a solution prepared by dissolving TCPB-Br2 (0.0013 mmol, 0.965 mg) in 0.5 mL of DEF was added into the prepared node solution. Additional 0.45 mL of formic acid was added. After heating at 120 °C for 3 days, rod-shaped single crystals formed.

Synthesis of <bold>Ce-NU-1008</bold>

In a 1.5 dram vial with TCPB-Br2 (0.0533 mmol, 38.2 mg) dissolved in 1.2 mL of DMF, aqueous ammonium cerium nitrate solution (0.4 mL, 1.066 M) and formic acid (0.258 mL) were added in sequence. The mixture was placed on the aluminum hot plate and then stirred under 100 °C for 5 min. The generated light-yellow powder was centrifuged out of the solution and washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

Synthesis of <bold>Th-NU-1008</bold>

400 μL of solution A (1000 mg Th­(NO3)4·5H2O dissolved in 20 mL DMF) and 400 μL of solution B (100 mg TCPB-Br2 in 10 mL DMF) were added to a 1.5 dram vial with 100 μL of H2O, and 100 μL of solution C (5 g benzoic acid in 10 mL DMF) was added, resulting in a clear solution. Twenty sample vials were prepared under the same conditions at once and were placed into an oil bath at 120 °C for 30 min, during which time a white suspension formed. After cooling down to room temperature, the 20 vials were combined, and the solid was isolated by centrifugation. The sample was further washed with DMF and then soaked in formic acid/DMF (1:10) overnight to replace benzoic acid with formic acid. After benzoic acid removal, the material was further washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

CO<sub>2</sub> Cycloaddition of Styrene Oxide

Batch reactions were carried out in a Parr reactor by using M-NU-1008 as catalysts for CO2 fixation into styrene oxide. Styrene oxide (0.2 mmol), tetrabutylammonium bromide (6.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) predissolved in 400 μL of acetonitrile, and MOF material (0.002 mmol) were added to an autoclave reactor, which was previously dried for 6 h at 80 °C. The autoclave reactor was evacuated, purged with CO2, and then placed under a constant pressure of CO2 at 5 bar for 15 min to allow the system to equilibrate. Then the pressure was reduced to 1 bar of gauge pressure, and the reaction was carried out at room temperature. After catalyst separation by centrifugation, a small aliquot of the supernatant reaction mixture was taken to be analyzed by 1H NMR to calculate the conversion of the reaction.

After benzoic acid removal, the material was further washed with DMF (5 mL × 3) and ethanol (5 mL × 3). The material was soaked in ethanol overnight and then activated by flowing supercritical CO2.

CO2 Cycloaddition of Styrene Oxide

Batch reactions were carried out in a Parr reactor by using M-NU-1008 as catalysts for CO2 fixation into styrene oxide. Styrene oxide (0.2 mmol), tetrabutylammonium bromide (6.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) predissolved in 400 μL of acetonitrile, and MOF material (0.002 mmol) were added to an autoclave reactor, which was previously dried for 6 h at 80 °C. The autoclave reactor was evacuated, purged with CO2, and then placed under a constant pressure of CO2 at 5 bar for 15 min to allow the system to equilibrate. Then the pressure was reduced to 1 bar of gauge pressure, and the reaction was carried out at room temperature. After catalyst separation by centrifugation, a small aliquot of the supernatant reaction mixture was taken to be analyzed by 1H NMR to calculate the conversion of the reaction.

metadata.title:
Exploring the Role of Hexanuclear Clusters as Lewis
Acidic Sites in Isostructural Metal–Organic Frameworks
